overview_of_class: In this seminar we will examine the nature of the mind from both Buddhist and traditional Western psychological perspectives. We will employ a Buddhist technique for investigating mental activity by incorporating a brief meditation period into class and homework activities. We will also examine written materials from both traditions, and these will form the primary basis for class discussion and examinations.

descriptions.value: In this seminar we will examine the nature of the mind from both Buddhist and traditional Western psychological perspectives. We will employ a Buddhist technique for investigating mental activity by incorporating a brief meditation period into class and homework activities. We will also examine written materials from both traditions, and these will form the primary basis for class discussion and examinations.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: By the end of the class the student will be expected to have a strong understanding of the relationship between the Buddhist Psychological framework and the related current theories from scientific Psychology.

Students will be expected to submit questions on the readings prior to each class.

overview_of_class: Lots of people have beliefs that other people think are just plain weird. Why do people have these beliefs? We'll look at "weird" beliefs within our culture as well as some cross-cultural examples, and try to understand what leads people to develop and maintain these beliefs. Another issue is that one person's "weird" belief may be another person's firmly held conviction. From this perspective, we'll also try to understand which beliefs are rational. Among the topics we may cover are: superstition, parapsychology, ghosts, witchcraft, alien abduction, evolution vs. creationism, repressed memories of abuse, and dissociative identity disorder. Students will use a wide variety of academic and popular media resources (including empirical research articles, ethnographic descriptions, philosophical arguments, popular press books, and documentary films) to explore the bases for these beliefs and practices.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Primarily discussion supplemented with videos and some brief lectures.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Grades will be based on weekly written discussion questions, an independent research paper, and class participation.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
In addition to the required books, we will have articles and chapters from a variety of other sources that will be available through the Canvas course management system. The required books are most likely to be:
1. Clancy, S.A. (2005). Abducted: How people come to believe they were kidnapped by aliens. Harvard University Press. ISBN: 0-674-01879-6
2. Gilovich, T. (1991). How we know what isn't so: The fallibility of human reason in everyday life. Free Press. ISBN: 0-02-911706-2
3. Miller, K.R. (2008). Only a theory: Evolution and the battle for America's soul. Viking Press. ISBN: 978-0143115663
4. Sagan, C. (1996). The demon-haunted world. Ballantine Books. ISBN: 0-345-40946-9
5. Shermer, M. (2011). The believing brain. New York: Henry Holt. ISBN: 978-0-8050-9125-0
6. Wiseman, R. (2010). Paranormality: Why we see what isn't there. ISBN: 978-0-9568756-5-5
